Optimizing Anabolic Response:

  • Volume: Multiple sets better than single sets
  • Load: 70-85% 1RM optimal for GH
  • Rest: Shorter rest (30-90 sec) increases GH
  • Exercise selection: Multi-joint, large muscle groups
  • Nutrition: Protein + carbs post-workout enhances insulin response
  • Sleep: GH released during deep sleep
  • Recovery: Adequate rest between sessions

Age and Sex Differences:

  • Men vs Women: Men have higher testosterone but similar GH response
  • Older adults: Blunted hormonal response but still beneficial
  • Can still build muscle: Even with lower hormonal response

Exam Tips:

üéØ Must know:

  • Anabolic: Testosterone, GH, IGF-1, insulin ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Catabolic: Cortisol, glucagon ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Resistance training increases anabolic hormones acutely ‚úì‚úì
  • Overtraining increases cortisol chronically ‚úì
  • T:C ratio indicator of recovery status

Question 183: Exercise and Cognitive Function

How does regular exercise affect cognitive function and brain health?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Improves memory, executive function, and processing speed; increases BDNF; reduces dementia risk 30-40%; most effective with combined aerobic + resistance training

Extended Explanation:

Cognitive Benefits of Exercise:

Memory Improvements:

  • Working memory: Better short-term information processing ‚úì
  • Long-term memory: Enhanced recall and consolidation
  • Spatial memory: Improved navigation and spatial awareness
  • Hippocampus: Exercise increases hippocampal volume (memory center)

Executive Function:

  • Planning and organization: Better task management ‚úì‚úì
  • Inhibitory control: Improved self-regulation
  • Cognitive flexibility: Switching between tasks
  • Decision making: Enhanced problem-solving

Processing Speed:

  • Faster information processing
  • Improved reaction time
  • Better attention and focus

Mechanisms - How Exercise Affects the Brain:

1. BDNF (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor):

  • Exercise increases BDNF production ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Function: Promotes neuron growth, survival, synaptic plasticity
  • Called: "Miracle-Gro for the brain"
  • Areas affected: Hippocampus, prefrontal cortex

2. Neurogenesis:

  • Exercise stimulates new neuron formation
  • Particularly in hippocampus (memory)
  • Counters age-related neuronal loss

3. Cerebral Blood Flow:

  • Increased blood flow to brain
  • Better oxygen and nutrient delivery
  • Angiogenesis (new blood vessel formation)

4. Reduced Inflammation:

  • Lower systemic inflammation
  • Reduced neuroinflammation
  • Protection against neurodegenerative processes

5. Neurotransmitter Changes:

  • Dopamine ‚Üë: Motivation, reward, learning
  • Serotonin ‚Üë: Mood, sleep, cognition
  • Norepinephrine ‚Üë: Attention, arousal

Dementia and Alzheimer's Prevention:

  • Risk reduction: 30-40% with regular exercise ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Delays onset: Even in high-risk individuals (APOE4 carriers)
  • Slows progression: In those with MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment)
  • Mechanism: Reduced amyloid plaques, improved tau clearance

Optimal Exercise for Brain Health:

Type:

  • Aerobic exercise: Strong evidence for cognitive benefits
  • Resistance training: Also effective, especially for executive function
  • Best: Combined aerobic + resistance ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Coordination activities: Dance, tai chi (added cognitive challenge)

Dose:

  • Frequency: 3-5 days/week minimum
  • Duration: 30-60 minutes per session
  • Intensity: Moderate to vigorous
  • Volume: 150+ minutes/week

Age-Specific Benefits:

Children and Adolescents:

  • Better academic performance
  • Improved attention in ADHD
  • Enhanced brain development

Middle-Aged Adults:

  • Maintains cognitive function
  • Builds "cognitive reserve"
  • Reduces future dementia risk

Older Adults:

  • Greatest cognitive benefits ‚úì‚úì
  • Counters age-related decline
  • Improves quality of life
  • Never too late to start

Acute vs Chronic Effects:

Acute (Single Session):

  • Improved attention and processing immediately after
  • Enhanced memory consolidation
  • Better mood and reduced stress
  • Lasts 1-4 hours post-exercise

Chronic (Regular Training):

  • Structural brain changes (volume increases)
  • Improved baseline cognitive function
  • Long-term neuroprotection
  • Requires weeks to months to develop

Exam Tips:

üéØ Critical facts:

  • Improves: Memory, executive function, processing speed ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • BDNF increases with exercise ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Reduces dementia risk 30-40% ‚úì‚úì
  • Best: Aerobic + resistance combined ‚úì‚úì
  • Greatest benefits in older adults ‚úì
  • Dose: 150+ min/week moderate-vigorous

Question 184: DOMS (Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness)

What causes DOMS, when does it occur, and how should it be treated?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Caused by eccentric exercise-induced muscle damage; onset 12-24 hrs, peak 24-72 hrs, resolves 5-7 days; treat with light active recovery (not complete rest)

Extended Explanation:

What is DOMS?

  • Definition: Muscle soreness and stiffness occurring after unaccustomed exercise ‚úì‚úì
  • Not the same as: Acute pain during exercise (muscle strain)
  • Normal response: Part of adaptation process

Cause - Eccentric Muscle Damage:

  • Primary cause: Eccentric contractions (muscle lengthening under load) ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Mechanism: Microscopic tears in muscle fibers (Z-line disruption)
  • Especially after: New exercises, increased volume/intensity, downhill running
  • Not lactic acid: Common misconception - lactate clears within hours

Time Course:

  • Onset: 12-24 hours post-exercise ‚úì
  • Peak: 24-72 hours (typically 48 hours) ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Resolution: 5-7 days
  • Symptoms: Soreness, stiffness, reduced ROM, temporary strength loss

Repeated Bout Effect:

  • Adaptation occurs: Less DOMS with subsequent identical workouts ‚úì‚úì
  • Protection lasts: 6-9 weeks after single bout
  • Mechanism: Structural adaptations, improved eccentric strength
  • Clinical relevance: Start new clients light and progress gradually

Treatment:

Most Effective:

  • Light active recovery: Low-intensity exercise (walking, easy cycling) ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Why it works: Increases blood flow without further damage
  • Better than: Complete rest

Other Strategies:

  • Massage: May provide temporary relief
  • Ice: Limited evidence, may reduce discomfort
  • NSAIDs: Reduce pain but may impair adaptation
  • Stretching: Does NOT prevent or treat DOMS
  • Foam rolling: May reduce perception of soreness

Prevention:

  • Progressive overload: Gradual increases in volume/intensity
  • Proper warm-up: Prepares muscles
  • Gradual eccentric loading: Start light with new exercises
  • Cannot completely prevent: Some DOMS normal with novel stimuli

Training With DOMS:

  • Can train: Different muscle groups or light activity
  • Avoid: Heavy loading of same muscles
  • Doesn't mean: Muscle damage is still occurring
  • Safe to exercise: Unless pain is severe or affects function

Exam Tips:

  • Cause: Eccentric exercise ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Peak: 24-72 hours ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Treatment: Light active recovery ‚úì‚úì
  • Repeated bout effect: Less DOMS with subsequent sessions ‚úì‚úì

Question 185: Exercise for Frailty in Older Adults

What is the appropriate exercise prescription for older adults with frailty?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Multicomponent program (aerobic + resistance + balance); 3-5 days/week; start very low intensity; progress slowly over months; can reverse frailty

Extended Explanation:

Frailty Definition:

  • Syndrome: Decreased physiological reserve, multiple system impairments ‚úì
  • Criteria (3+ present):
    • Unintentional weight loss (>10 lbs/year)
    • Self-reported exhaustion
    • Weakness (poor grip strength)
    • Slow walking speed (<0.8 m/s)
    • Low physical activity
  • Prevalence: 7% age 65+, 20% age 80+

Multicomponent Exercise Prescription:

1. Resistance Training:

  • Frequency: 2-3 days/week ‚úì
  • Intensity: Start bodyweight or very light (RPE 11-13)
  • Exercises: Chair stands, wall push-ups, light dumbbells
  • Progression: Add resistance very gradually
  • Focus: Lower body strength (functional)

2. Aerobic Training:

  • Frequency: 3-5 days/week ‚úì
  • Intensity: Light to moderate (40-50% HRR initially)
  • Duration: Start 5-10 min, build to 30+ min
  • Mode: Walking, recumbent bike, aquatic exercise

3. Balance Training:

  • Frequency: 3-7 days/week ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Essential for: Fall prevention
  • Exercises: Standing on one leg, heel-to-toe walk, tai chi
  • Progression: Reduce base of support, remove visual input

4. Flexibility:

  • Frequency: Daily preferred
  • Focus: Major joints, maintain ROM

Starting Guidelines:

  • Start very low: Below what seems necessary ‚úì
  • Duration: 5-10 minutes initially
  • Intensity: "Can talk comfortably throughout"
  • Supervision: Close monitoring initially
  • Medical clearance: Recommended given multiple conditions

Progression:

  • Timeline: Months not weeks ‚úì‚úì
  • Increase: Duration before intensity
  • Small increments: 2-5 minutes per week
  • Monitor closely: Fatigue, pain, adverse events

Benefits - Can Reverse Frailty:

  • Improved strength: 20-30% gains possible ‚úì‚úì
  • Better mobility: Increased walking speed
  • Reduced falls: 30-40% reduction
  • Improved independence: Better ADL performance
  • Reverses frailty status: Can move from frail to pre-frail/robust ‚úì‚úì‚úì

Safety Considerations:

  • Fall risk: Have support nearby, use assistive devices
  • Multiple medications: Watch for interactions
  • Cognitive impairment: Simple instructions, repetition
  • Environmental: Clear space, good lighting, non-slip surfaces

Exam Tips:

  • Multicomponent: Aerobic + resistance + balance ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Start very low intensity ‚úì‚úì
  • Progress slowly (months) ‚úì
  • Can reverse frailty ‚úì‚úì

Question 186: Aerobic and Anaerobic Threshold

Define aerobic threshold and anaerobic threshold. How do they differ?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Aerobic threshold: First rise in lactate (~55-65% VO2max); Anaerobic threshold (lactate threshold): Point where lactate accumulation accelerates (~70-85% VO2max); both mark sustainable vs unsustainable pace boundaries

Extended Explanation:

Aerobic Threshold (AerT):

  • Definition: First detectable increase in blood lactate above baseline ‚úì
  • Occurs at: ~55-65% VO2max (untrained individuals)
  • Also called: Lactate threshold 1 (LT1)
  • Blood lactate: ~2 mmol/L
  • Significance: Upper limit of "easy" aerobic exercise

Anaerobic Threshold (AnT):

  • Definition: Point where lactate accumulation accelerates ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Occurs at: ~70-85% VO2max (varies with training)
  • Also called: Lactate threshold (LT), lactate threshold 2 (LT2)
  • Blood lactate: ~4 mmol/L (OBLA - Onset of Blood Lactate Accumulation)
  • Best performance predictor: For endurance events ‚úì‚úì

Training Zones Based on Thresholds:

Zone 1 - Below Aerobic Threshold:

  • Easy recovery pace
  • Sustainable for hours
  • Fat as primary fuel
  • Conversational pace

Zone 2 - Between AerT and AnT:

  • Moderate intensity
  • Can talk but harder
  • Mixed fuel use
  • Tempo/threshold training

Zone 3 - Above Anaerobic Threshold:

  • High intensity
  • Time-limited (minutes to <1 hour)
  • Lactate accumulation
  • Interval training

Training Effects:

  • Untrained: AnT at ~50-60% VO2max
  • Trained: AnT at 70-85% VO2max ‚úì
  • Elite: AnT at 85-95% VO2max
  • Trainable: Both thresholds shift rightward with training

Exam Tips:

  • AerT: ~55-65% VO2max, first lactate rise ‚úì
  • AnT: ~70-85% VO2max, lactate accumulation ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • AnT = best performance predictor ‚úì

Question 187: Exercise and Bone Health

What types of exercise are best for bone health and why?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Weight-bearing + high-impact activities (running, jumping, resistance training); mechanical loading stimulates osteoblasts; critical during youth and post-menopause; swimming/cycling less effective

Extended Explanation:

Best Exercises for Bone:

  • Weight-bearing aerobic: Running, walking, tennis, dancing ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • High-impact: Jumping, plyometrics (when appropriate)
  • Resistance training: All major muscle groups, progressive loading ‚úì‚úì
  • Combination best: Impact + resistance

Less Effective:

  • Swimming: Non-weight-bearing (minimal bone stress)
  • Cycling: Minimal impact forces
  • Still beneficial for: Cardiovascular health, but not optimal for bone

Mechanism - Wolff's Law:

  • Principle: Bone adapts to mechanical stress ‚úì
  • Loading stimulates: Osteoblasts (bone-building cells)
  • Reduces: Osteoclast activity (bone breakdown)
  • Site-specific: Loading must be applied to target bones

Critical Periods:

Youth (Pre-Puberty to Age 30):

  • Peak bone mass: Achieved by late 20s/early 30s ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Most responsive: Bone most sensitive to loading
  • Critical for: Building "bone bank" for later life
  • Impact greatest: During rapid growth periods

Post-Menopause (Women):

  • Rapid bone loss: 1-2% per year initially ‚úì‚úì
  • Estrogen decline: Reduces bone protection
  • Exercise critical: Can slow/prevent loss
  • Never too late: Benefits at any age

Recommendations:

  • Impact activities: 3-5 days/week
  • Resistance training: 2-3 days/week, progressive
  • Intensity: Moderate to high loads needed
  • Variety: Multiple directions of force

Contraindications:

  • Severe osteoporosis: Avoid high-impact (fracture risk)
  • Vertebral fractures: Avoid spinal flexion exercises
  • Modify to: Lower impact but still weight-bearing

Exam Tips:

  • Best: Weight-bearing + high-impact ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Resistance training effective ‚úì‚úì
  • Swimming/cycling less effective ‚úì
  • Critical: Youth and post-menopause ‚úì

Question 188: Facility Risk Management

What are the key components of facility risk management for exercise facilities?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Waivers/informed consent, liability insurance, emergency procedures/staff training, equipment maintenance, pre-participation screening, proper supervision

Key Risk Management Components:

  • Waivers: Informed consent, assumption of risk ‚úì‚úì
  • Insurance: Professional liability, facility coverage
  • Emergency procedures: Written protocols, regular drills ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Equipment maintenance: Regular inspection, documentation
  • Staff credentials: Current CPR/AED, certifications
  • Screening: PAR-Q+, health history

Question 189: Thermoregulation During Exercise

What is the primary mechanism of thermoregulation during exercise?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Evaporation through sweating; also radiation, convection, conduction; acclimatization takes 10-14 days

Heat Dissipation Mechanisms:

  • Evaporation (primary): Sweating ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Radiation: Heat transfer to cooler surroundings
  • Convection: Moving air removes heat
  • Conduction: Direct contact with cooler surface

Heat Acclimatization:

  • Timeline: 10-14 days ‚úì‚úì
  • Adaptations: Earlier sweating, higher sweat rate, dilute sweat (conserve sodium)
  • Method: Daily heat exposure 60-90 min

Question 190: Exercise and Mental Health

How effective is exercise for treating depression and anxiety?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Reduces depression comparable to medication; decreases anxiety; improves self-esteem; dose: 30-60 min, 3-5 days/week, moderate intensity

Mental Health Benefits:

  • Depression: Reduces symptoms comparable to antidepressants ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Anxiety: Decreases both state and trait anxiety ‚úì‚úì
  • Self-esteem: Improves body image and confidence
  • Stress: Reduces cortisol, improves coping

Optimal Dose:

  • Intensity: Moderate (not necessarily vigorous)
  • Duration: 30-60 minutes
  • Frequency: 3-5 days/week ‚úì
  • Type: Aerobic most studied, resistance also effective

Question 191: Youth Resistance Training

Is resistance training safe for children and adolescents? What guidelines apply?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Safe with proper supervision, appropriate loads, technique focus; can start age 7-8; emphasize form not weight; no 1RM testing prepubescent; benefits include strength, bone density, injury prevention

Safety Guidelines:

  • Age: Can start 7-8 years with bodyweight ‚úì‚úì
  • Supervision: Qualified instructor required ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Focus: Technique and control, not maximal weight ‚úì‚úì
  • Avoid: 1RM testing in prepubescent children ‚úì
  • Progression: Add resistance only after perfect form

Benefits:

  • Increased strength (15-30% gains)
  • Improved bone density
  • Injury prevention (sports)
  • Enhanced motor skills
  • Improved self-esteem

Question 192: Metabolic Cart Quality Control

What quality control procedures are required for metabolic cart testing?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Calibrate daily before testing; verify gas analyzers with known calibration gases; check flow sensor with 3L syringe; leak check system; regular manufacturer service

Daily Calibration:

  • Gas analyzers: Verify with calibration gases (known O2/CO2%) ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Flow sensor: Check with 3L calibration syringe ‚úì‚úì
  • Leak check: Ensure sealed system
  • Timing: Before each testing session

Maintenance:

  • Regular manufacturer service
  • Replace sensors as needed
  • Clean mouthpieces/tubing
  • Document all calibrations

Question 193: Exercise and Glycemic Control

How does exercise affect insulin sensitivity and glycemic control?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Increases insulin sensitivity 24-72 hours post-exercise; glucose uptake independent of insulin (contraction-mediated); improves HbA1c 0.6-0.7%; effect lost after 3-5 days without exercise

Insulin Sensitivity:

  • Increases: 24-72 hours after exercise ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Mechanism: Enhanced GLUT4 translocation
  • Duration: Effect lost after 3-5 days no exercise ‚úì‚úì
  • Requires: Regular consistent exercise

Glucose Uptake:

  • Contraction-mediated: Independent of insulin ‚úì‚úì
  • Acute effect: Lowers blood glucose during/after exercise
  • Chronic effect: Improves overall control

HbA1c Reduction:

  • Improvement: 0.6-0.7% reduction ‚úì
  • Clinical significance: Reduces diabetes complications
  • Best: Aerobic + resistance combined

Question 194: Movement Screening

What are common movement screening tools and their purposes?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
FMS (Functional Movement Screen): 7 movements scored 0-3; Y-Balance Test: dynamic balance; identify asymmetries and injury risk; guide corrective exercise; not diagnostic

FMS (Functional Movement Screen):

  • 7 movements: Each scored 0-3 ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Tests: Deep squat, hurdle step, in-line lunge, shoulder mobility, active straight leg raise, trunk stability push-up, rotary stability
  • Purpose: Identify movement limitations
  • Score <14: Associated with increased injury risk

Y-Balance Test:

  • Assesses: Dynamic balance in 3 directions ‚úì
  • Asymmetries: >4 cm difference = injury risk
  • Applications: Return to sport, fall risk

Important Note:

  • Not diagnostic: Screening tools, not medical diagnosis ‚úì
  • Guide: Corrective exercise prescription
  • Limitations: Moderate predictive value

Question 195: Cancer Exercise During Treatment

Can cancer patients exercise during active treatment (chemotherapy/radiation)?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Yes, generally safe for most; reduces fatigue better than rest; individualize based on side effects; monitor blood counts (avoid if severe anemia/neutropenia); similar guidelines to general population with modifications

Safety During Treatment:

  • Generally safe: Most can exercise during chemo/radiation ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Benefits: Reduces fatigue (better than rest) ‚úì‚úì
  • Maintains: Functional capacity, quality of life

Contraindications:

  • Severe anemia: Hemoglobin <8 g/dL ‚úì
  • Neutropenia: Risk of infection
  • Fever: >38¬∞C (100.4¬∞F)
  • Severe nausea/vomiting: Active symptoms
  • Bone metastases: At risk sites

Recommendations:

  • Guidelines: Similar to general population
  • Individualize: Based on treatment side effects ‚úì
  • Adjust intensity: As tolerated day-to-day
  • Frequency: Most days of week if possible

Question 196: Cardiac Rehabilitation Phases

Describe the phases of cardiac rehabilitation.
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Phase I: Inpatient (bedside mobilization, ADLs); Phase II: Outpatient supervised (12 weeks, 3x/week, ECG monitored); Phase III: Maintenance (ongoing, less supervision); Phase IV: Community-based

Phase I - Inpatient:

  • Duration: Hospital stay (3-5 days) ‚úì
  • Activities: Bedside mobilization, ADLs, hallway walks
  • Intensity: Very low, progress to 2-3 METs
  • Goals: Prevent deconditioning, assess readiness

Phase II - Outpatient Supervised:

  • Duration: 12 weeks (up to 36 sessions) ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Frequency: 3x/week minimum
  • Monitoring: ECG telemetry, BP, symptoms ‚úì‚úì
  • Exercise: Aerobic + resistance + education
  • Intensity: 40-80% HRR or VO2R

Phase III - Maintenance:

  • Duration: Ongoing indefinitely
  • Supervision: Reduced, periodic check-ins
  • Location: Facility-based or home

Phase IV - Community:

  • Independent: Community fitness facilities
  • Self-monitored: Minimal professional supervision

Question 197: Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage Recovery

What aids recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Eccentric causes most damage; peaks 24-48 hrs; protein (20-25g) + carbs post-exercise; 7-9 hours sleep; active recovery; repeated bout effect reduces subsequent damage

Recovery Strategies:

  • Nutrition: Protein 20-25g + carbs within 2 hours ‚úì‚úì
  • Sleep: 7-9 hours critical for recovery ‚úì‚úì
  • Active recovery: Light movement better than rest ‚úì
  • Hydration: Adequate fluid replacement

Timeline:

  • Damage peaks: 24-48 hours ‚úì
  • Full recovery: 5-7 days
  • Repeated bout: Less damage next time ‚úì‚úì

Question 198: Motivational Interviewing

What is the OARS approach in motivational interviewing?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Open questions, Affirmations, Reflective listening, Summaries; client-centered approach to resolve ambivalence and support autonomy

OARS Techniques:

  • O - Open questions: Cannot answer yes/no ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • A - Affirmations: Recognize strengths ‚úì‚úì
  • R - Reflective listening: Paraphrase to show understanding ‚úì‚úì
  • S - Summaries: Pull together conversation ‚úì‚úì

MI Spirit:

  • Partnership (collaboration)
  • Acceptance (unconditional positive regard)
  • Compassion (prioritize client welfare)
  • Evocation (draw out client's motivations)

Goal:

  • Resolve ambivalence about change
  • Support client autonomy
  • Elicit "change talk"
  • Avoid "righting reflex" (telling what to do)

Question 199: Older Adult Functional Testing

What functional tests are used to assess older adults?
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Gait speed (<0.8 m/s = mobility limitation); Chair stand (30-sec or 5-rep timed); TUG >12 sec = fall risk; 6-minute walk (functional capacity); Single-leg stance (balance)

Key Functional Tests:

Gait Speed:

  • Cutoff: <0.8 m/s = mobility limitation ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Distance: Usually 4 meters
  • Predicts: Hospitalization, disability, mortality

Chair Stand Test:

  • 30-second: Count repetitions ‚úì
  • 5-rep: Time to complete 5 stands
  • Assesses: Lower body strength

TUG (Timed Up and Go):

  • Protocol: Stand from chair, walk 3m, turn, return, sit ‚úì
  • Cutoff: >12 seconds = fall risk ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Assesses: Mobility, balance, fall risk

6-Minute Walk:

  • Distance walked: In 6 minutes
  • Assesses: Functional aerobic capacity
  • Submaximal: Self-paced

Balance Tests:

  • Single-leg stance (eyes open/closed)
  • Tandem stand
  • Berg Balance Scale (14 items)

Question 200: Comprehensive Case Integration

Describe the comprehensive approach to working with a new client as an Exercise Physiologist.
‚úì CORRECT ANSWER:
Integrate all competencies: risk stratification, exercise prescription (FITT-VP all components), behavior change strategies, emergency preparedness, special population modifications, scope of practice, professional communication

Comprehensive EP Approach:

1. Risk Stratification:

  • Screen with PAR-Q+ or health history ‚úì‚úì
  • Classify as low/moderate/high risk
  • Determine if medical clearance needed
  • Identify contraindications

2. Exercise Prescription - FITT-VP:

  • Aerobic: F, I, T, T, V, P ‚úì‚úì‚úì
  • Resistance: All major muscle groups
  • Flexibility: 2-3 days/week minimum
  • Neuromotor: 2-3 days/week for older adults

3. Behavior Change:

  • Assess stage of change (TTM) ‚úì
  • Apply motivational interviewing techniques
  • Set SMART goals
  • Provide social support

4. Special Population Modifications:

  • Adjust for medical conditions ‚úì‚úì
  • Consider medications
  • Age-appropriate guidelines
  • Functional limitations

5. Emergency Preparedness:

  • Know emergency signs/symptoms ‚úì
  • Emergency action plan in place
  • CPR/AED certified
  • Phone/AED accessible

6. Scope of Practice:

  • Stay within EP boundaries ‚úì‚úì
  • Refer when appropriate (RD, PT, physician)
  • No diagnosis or treatment
  • General nutrition only

7. Professional Practice:

  • Document all sessions
  • Maintain confidentiality
  • Continue education
  • Evidence-based practice

Exam Reminder:

This question tests your ability to integrate ALL ACSM-EP competencies into real-world practice. Be prepared for case studies that require you to apply multiple concepts simultaneously.

üìë Page Navigation:
